Congress wants to tighten funding rules to make companies put more money into their pension funds.

Lynn Dudley works for the American Benefits Council, an advocacy group for corporate benefit plans.
Some will leave because the combination of funding and competition will force them to do it.

She says the new rules would leave companies vulnerable to the ups and downs of the financial markets.
It could also force them to set aside more money than is actually needed.
And it makes it much harder from a business perspective to take money and invest it in jobs or invest it in research or in product development if you're having to set it aside in case you need it.
Traditional pensions - which pay a fixed amount of money each month -were once the bedrock of the American retirement system.

Well, I think it's two things.
One, I have to say, that, when I was restaurant critic, I lived in terror of making that kind of mistake.
Of, you know, calling a turnip a rutabaga.
